name: Online Data Collection and Management
description: Learn how to scrape the web!

items.name: Install Anaconda
items.description: Anaconda is a Python distribution and set you up with everything that you need to work with Python!

items.name: Verify that you have a premium account at Datacamp
items.description: We use Datacamp in this class, but you need to go through a quite cumbersome onboarding procedure with the University library. Do this soon so you can enjoy premium content without having to pay for it!

items.name: Launch Jupyter Notebook
items.description: Know how to launch Jupyter Notebook -- both locally on your computer, and in your browser via Google Colab.

items.name: Get familiar with Jupyter Notebook
items.description: Get comfortable using Jupyter Notebook, by completing exercises 2.1-2.5 from the in-class tutorial independently.

items.name: Crawl data from Reddit.com
items.description: Complete exercises 3.1 and 3.2 from the tutorial independently!

items.name: Wrap code in functions, and store data from Reddit.com
items.description: Learn why wrapping code in functions makes sense (plus makes your code look more beautiful); then, proceed to store your data in the JSON format. Please complete exercises 3.3 and 3.4 from the tutorial independently.

items.name: Repeatedly execute your code using loops
items.description: Collecting web data is all about re-running collection code over and over again - complete exercises 3.5-3.7 independently to save data in files.

items.name: Complete the final exercise of the tutorial - your first API data collection!
items.description: Try working on the task in section 3.9 -- your first complete data collection using all of the concepts you've learnt in the tutorial so far.

items.name: Work through the Datacamp.com tutorial
items.description: After class, you can deepen your Python knowledge by completing a tutorial at Datacamp.com. Please work on the first three chapters only.

items.name: Watch the energizer for this week
items.description: To get acquainted with this week's course material, watch the energizer!

items.name: Watch the video on what web scraping and APIs are
items.description: This 30-minute video explains the differences between web scraping and APIs, and is a good way to get started.

items.name: Watch the webinar
items.description: This 60-minute webinar gives you the main highlights of the Fields of Gold paper. Pay attention to (a) potential research ideas and (b) understanding the main challenges when scraping data.

items.name: Thoroughly read the Fields of Gold paper
items.description: It's time to get into the details: thoroughly read the paper, providing you a framework for this class.

items.category_name: 3. Tutorial: Web data for dummies (web scraping, after-class exercises)

items.name: Understand the definition of web scraping and how this differs from using APIs
items.description: We can use web scraping to extract information from a given website, which we can then save or analyze, for example. This way, we do not lose valuable information when a site is updated!

items.name: Understand the html structure of the book presented in the tutorial (A Light in the Attic)!
items.description: Inspect the web page and look at the structure at which the page is setup. You will see that information such as the title and price is surrounded by corresponding tags, which we later on use to extract this data!

items.name: Use the requests library to extract the book title or product description!
items.description: By using the requests library, we load the source code of the website into Python, allowing us to extract our preferred data from the web page!

items.name: Simplify your search by using the BeautifulSoup library to get your desired piece of data!
items.description: As you most likely noticed, the BeautifulSoup library is a much more convenient way to scrape the data. Use the .find() or .get_text() methods and combine these with indices to capture the website's content!

items.category_name: 4. Tutorial: Web data for dummies (APIs, after-class exercises)

items.name: Understand the definition of APIs and how this differs from using web scraping
items.description: Contrary to web scraping (which you use software for extract data), APIs are designed to extract data from a website and give you access to it. They are, therefore, a more legit way to retrieve data - but are also limited in providing the data

items.name: Understand the structure of a JSON tree and how data is stored within these trees
items.description: The JSON tree is basically the backend of what the output shows. Lists and dictionaries are used to store the data. Navigate through the tree to get a grasp of how the data is structured and to what parent each piece belongs to!

items.name: Print out a random joke from the presented website by following the steps for using an API!
items.description: By providing Python with a URL and the proper headers, we can extract the data from the website (which is a random joke each time). Tip: Make sure you imported the requests library!

items.name: Rather than simply printing out a random joke, try saving multiple ones within an empty list by using a for-loop
items.description: When collecting data, you most likely want to store it (temporarily). Therefore, try collecting a few jokes within an empty list!

items.name: Watch the energizer for this week
items.description: To get acquainted with this week's course material, watch the energizer!

items.name: Install selenium and chromedriver, and launch the automated browser on your computer
items.description: In this tutorial, you learn a new way of retrieving web data using an automated browser that you can view while the scraping takes place. This will not work in Colab, but you must use your own computers.

items.name: Understand when to make website requests using `requests` vs `selenium`
items.description: Some websites are not accessible when using the simple requests library. Learn hear how to still conduct scraping by simulating browsing behavior you can follow on your screen.

items.name: Collect titles / urls using selenium and requests (exercise 1.1)
items.description: Apply two technologies to extract web data.

items.name: Run and understand a function that extracts all the book titles and URLs (exercise 2.2)
items.description: Often times, websites get updated with new information (e.g., new books are added). Therefore, we automate our scraper, such that it still works and collects all the data when the website is updated!

items.name: Navigate on a website using URLs (exercises 3.1 and 3.2)
items.description: When scraping, we often want extract information from multiple pages. Here, you learn how to navigate to these pages using URLs.

items.name: Interactively navigate a website by clicking on buttons (exercise 3.3)
items.description: Dynamic websites require users to click buttons or keep on scrolling before some information is reveiled. Apply selenium to do so!

items.name: Extract all seeds (for your sample) from books.toscrape.com (exercise 3.4)
items.description: Apply your skills now to extracts product URLs from the book category at books.toscrape.com, and stores them in a list of dictionaries.

items.name: Modularize your code (exercise 4.2)
items.description: When moving your code into production, you need to 'clean it up' and modularize it.

items.name: Open a JSON file and parse some information (exercise 4.3)
items.description: After obtaining some raw data (e.g., seeds), you need to be able to open such information again in Python.

items.name: Completed after-class exercises
items.description: At the end of the notebook, you will find some after-class exercises. Are you able to complete them?

items.name: Understand the differences between Jupyter Notebook and Spyder or PyCharm
items.description: Jupyter Notebook is a great for people who are new to programming. As your skills improve, you may prefer an IDE such as Spyder or PyCharm over Notebook! You can run the code in Spyder to see how this differs from Notebook yourself.

modules.name: Week 4
modules.description: Learn how to extract data from APIs

items.name: Watch the energizer for this week
items.description: To get acquainted with this week's course material, watch the energizer!

items.name: Create a function that shows the number of jokes that include a specific search term
items.description: This function is the equivalent of searching for that term in the search bar on a website and shows how many jokes include it!

items.name: Extend this function by making it loop over all pages!
items.description: This extension allows you to collect all the jokes on the website without being restricted the current page!

items.name: Create a function that extracts the numbers of total and active users of a given subreddit
items.description: For this task, look how the .json url corresponds to the source code to extract the number of (active) users!

items.name: Analyze the reddit activity by using the 'after' attribute to apply pagination
items.description: Contrary to the sites we have seen thus far, Reddit does not have a 'next' page. Therefore, we use the next key each time to get the next batch of 25 comments and posts!

items.name: Write and run a function that extracts all the data (e.g., username, time a post was created etc.) of the first few pages of a subreddit
items.description: Rather than collecting snippets of the web page, we may want to extract as much information as possible and analyze it at a later instance. This function allows us to do so!

items.name: Write the results of this function to a csv file and try opening it to see the results!
items.description: To save our data, we export the data to a csv file so we can access it later or open it in another software program, for example!
